metadata.title: Chaos game representation dataset of SARS-CoV-2 genome Journal Pre-proof Chaos game representation dataset of SARS-CoV-2 genome Chaos game representation dataset of SARS-CoV-2 genome

affiliation.laboratory: Laboratory of Machine Learning and Intelligent Instrumentation
affiliation.institution: Federal University of Rio Grande do Norte

abstract.text: As of April 16, 2020, the novel coronavirus disease (called COVID-19) spread to more than 185 countries/regions with more than 142,000 deaths and more than 2,000,000 confirmed cases. In the bioinformatics area, one of the crucial points is the analysis of the virus nucleotide sequences using approaches such as data stream, digital signal processing, and machine learning techniques and algorithms. However, to make feasible this approach, it is necessary to transform the nucleotide sequences string to numerical values representation. Thus, the dataset provides a chaos game representation (CGR) of SARS-CoV-2 virus nucleotide sequences. The dataset provides the CGR of 100 instances of SARS-CoV-2 virus, 11540 instances of other viruses from the Virus-Host DB dataset, and three instances of Riboviria viruses from NCBI (Betacoronavirus RaTG13, bat-SL-CoVZC45, and bat-SL-CoVZXC21).

body_text.text: Biochemistry, Genetics and Molecular Biology (General) Specific subject area Bioinformatics Type of data

• These data are useful because they provide numeric representation of the COVID-2019 epidemic virus (SARS-CoV-2). With this form of the data, it is possible to use data stream, digital signal processing, and machine learning algorithms.

• All researchers in bioinformatics, computing science, and computing engineering field can benefit from these data because by using this numeric representation they can apply several techniques such as machine learning and digital signal processing in genomic information.
• Data experiments that use clustering and classification techniques in SARS-CoV-2 virus genomic information can be used with this dataset.
• These data represent an easy way to evaluate the SARS-CoV-2 virus genome. Each sub-directory "Matlab" contains three files called "RawDataTable-

where N is the length of sequence and s n is the n-th nucleotide of the sequence. Each n-th nucleotide, s n , is mapped to bi-dimensional symbol (s x (n), s y (n)) and it can be expressed as (
After the mapping, each n-th symbol (s x (n), s y (n)) is transformed in CGR values by equations expressed as p x (n) = 1 2 s x (n) + 1 2 p x (n − 1), for n = 1, . . . , N
and p y (n) = 1 2 s y (n) + 1 2 p y (n − 1), for n = 1, . . . , N

where for the initial condition, n = 0, p x (0) = α x and p y (0) = α y [7, 8]. The 41 dataset was generated with α x = 0 and α y = 0. Figures 1a, 1b, 1c and 1d   42 show a example of CGR points (p x (n), p y (n)) from dataset presented in this 43 work.

FIGREF0.text: This work presents a new dataset of a chaos game representation (CGR) 2 of SARS-CoV-2 virus nucleotide sequences. The dataset contains two kinds 3 of data, the raw data, and the processing data. The raw data is composed 4 of the 100 instances of the SARS-CoV-2 virus genome collected from the provides two groups of formats files for all data. In the first 11 group, all data are stored in Matlab file format (.mat), and in the second 12 group, part of the data is stored in Microsoft Excel (.xlsx) and another part 13 in the text file (.txt). The two groups have the same information. The data 14 is organized into three main directories: "SARS-CoV-2 data", "Virus-Host 15 DB data" and "Other viruses data." Each main directory is formed by two 16 sub-directories: "Matlab" and "Excel and txt."17

FIGREF1.text: they have the same information, however in the "RawDataTable.mat" the 21 attributes are stored in Matlab table format (after 2013b version) and in 22 "RawData.mat" the attributes are stored in Matlab cell arrays format. Each 23 "CGRData.mat" file stores the CGR values of all viruses presented in each 24 "RawDataTable.mat" and "RawData.mat" file. For the main directory "Virus-25 Host DB data", the CGR values are stored in 10 files where each k -th file is 26 called "RawData_k .mat."27

FIGREF2.text: each "CGRData" has the CGR of viruses presented in each "RawData.xlsx"31 file. The points of the CGR associated with each virus are stored in a text 32 file called "LocusName_COD.txt" where COD is the code (locus name) Game Representation (CGR), proposed by H. Joel Jeffrey in 36 [7], transforms the nucleotide sequence (DNA or RNA) to bi-dimensional 37 real values. The CGR maintains the statistical properties of the nucleotide 38 sequence, and it allows an investigation of the local and global patterns in 39 sequences [8, 9]. 40 The CGR has with input the nucleotide sequence, s, expressed as s = [s 1 , . . . , s n , . . . , s N ]

TABREF0.text: Parameters for data collection The entire dataset was generated using MAT-LAB 2019b on Windows operating system with Intel Core -i5 6500T 2.5 GHz quad-core processor with 16GB of RAM. Description of data collection The raw data were downloaded from NCBI -Genbank, and Virus-Host-DB. The CGR values were generated using Matlab.
